translated: Living beings: beings are said to be those that are frightened and those that are steady.

analyzed: tasāti yesam tasita taṇhāḥ appahīnāḥ yesam ca bhaya bheravāḥ appahīnāḥ

analyzed: kiṅkāraṇāḥ vuccanti tasā

original: Te tasanti uttasanti paritasanti bhāyanti santāsaṁ āpajjanti, taṅkāraṇā vuccanti tasā.
analyzed: te tasanti uttasanti paritasanti bhāyanti santāsam āpajjanti taṅkāraṇāḥ vuccanti tasā
translated: They are frightened, terrified, scared, afraid, and they experience fear and dread. For this reason they are called those that are frightened.

original: Thāvarāti yesaṁ tasitataṇhā pahīnā, yesañca bhayabheravā pahīnā.
analyzed: tasita taṇhā pahīnā bhaya bheravā pahīnā
translated: Those that are steady are those in whom craving that is fear and dread has been abandoned, and those in whom fear and dread have been abandoned.

analyzed: kiṅkāraṇā vuccanti thāvarā
translated: Why are they called those that are steady?

original: Te na tasanti na uttasanti na paritasanti na bhāyanti na santāsaṁ āpajjanti, taṅkāraṇā vuccanti thāvarā.
analyzed: te na tasanti na uttasanti na paritasanti na bhāyanti na santāsam āpajjanti taṅkāraṇāḥ vuccanti thāvarā
translated: They do not tremble, quake, quake strongly, or experience a quake of fear. They do not become frightened and terrified. For this reason it is said, ‘They are steady.’

analyzed: daṇḍanti tayaḥ daṇḍā  kāya daṇḍaḥ vacī daṇḍaḥ manaḥ daṇḍaḥ
translated: ‘Three kinds of punishment’:🔽there is punishment by body, punishment by speech, and punishment by mind.

original: Tividhaṁ kāyaduccaritaṁ kāyadaṇḍo, catubbidhaṁ vacīduccaritaṁ vacīdaṇḍo, tividhaṁ manoduccaritaṁ manodaṇḍo.🔽Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍanti sabbesu bhūtesu daṇḍaṁ nidhāya nidahitvā.
analyzed: tividham kāya duccaritam kāya daṇḍo catubbidham vacī duccaritam vacī daṇḍo tividham manaḥ duccaritam manodaṇḍo  sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍanti sabbesu bhūtesu daṇḍam nidhāya nidahitvā
translated: Three kinds of misconduct by body are punishment by body; four kinds of misconduct by speech are punishment by speech; three kinds of misconduct by mind are punishment by mind.

original: Oropayitvā samoropayitvā nikkhipitvā paṭippassambhitvāti sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṁ.
analyzed: oropayitvā samoropayitvā nikkhipitvā paṭippassambhitvā ati sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍa
translated: ‘Having laid aside the rod against all living beings’: having laid aside the rod, having deposited the rod, having put down the rod, having given up the rod, having abandoned the rod, having relinquished the rod, having thrown away the rod against all living beings.

original: Aviheṭhayaṁ aññatarampi tesanti ekamekampi sattaṁ pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā🔽satthena vā anduyā vā rajjuyā vā aviheṭhayanto, sabbepi satte pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā
analyzed: a viheṭhayam aññataram pi tesanti ekam ekam pi sattam pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā  satthena vā anduyā vā rajjuyā vā a viheṭhayantaḥ sabbe pi satte pāṇinā vā leḍḍunā vā
translated: ‘Not hurting anyone at all’: not hurting any being at all with the hand, with a clod, with a stick,

original: daṇḍena vā satthena vā anduyā vā rajjuyā vā aviheṭhayantoti—
analyzed: daṇḍena vā satthena vā anduyā vā rajjuyā vā a viheṭhayantā iti
translated: with a knife, with a snare, with a trap. Not hurting any being at all with the hand, with a clod, with a stick, with a knife, with a snare, with a trap.

analyzed: aviheṭhayam aññataram pi
translated: ‘Not hurting anyone at all.’

analyzed: na puttam iccheyya kutas sahāyanti

analyzed: na ati paṭikkhepaḥ

analyzed: puttā ti cattāro puttā

analyzed: ṭhānam phāsu nisajjanam phāsu sayanam phāsu ālapanam phāsu sallapana  ullapanam phāsu samullapanam  na puttam iccheyya kutas sahāyanti puttam pi naḥ iccheyya na sādiyeyya na patthayeyya
translated: Friends: those with whom it is easy to come and go, easy to associate with, easy to visit, easy to attend on, easy to converse with, easy to associate with on familiar terms, easy to have a discussion with, easy to have a conversation with, easy to have a chat with.🔽Why would he want a friend? He wouldn’t want a son, wouldn’t consent to a son, wouldn’t long for a son,

original: na pihayeyya nābhijappeyya, kuto mittaṁ vā sandiṭṭhaṁ vā sambhattaṁ vā sahāyaṁ vā
analyzed: na pihayeyya na abhijappeyya kutas mittam vā sandiṭṭham vā sambhattam vā sahāyam vā
translated: wouldn’t desire a son, wouldn’t approve of a son. Why would he want a friend, a companion, a relative, or an associate?🔽He wouldn’t want a friend, wouldn’t consent to a friend, wouldn’t long for a friend,

analyzed: iccheyya sādiyeyya patthayeyya pihayeyya abhijappeyya ati
translated: wouldn’t desire a friend, wouldn’t approve of a friend.

analyzed: na puttam iccheyya kutas sahāya
translated: Why would he want a friend?

analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti
translated: He should go alone like a horn of a rhinoceros.

original: Ekoti so paccekasambuddho pabbajjāsaṅkhātena eko, adutiyaṭṭhena eko, taṇhāya pahānaṭṭhena
analyzed: ekaḥ ti so paccekasambuddhaḥ pabbajjā saṅkhātena ekaḥ adutiya ṭṭhena ekaḥ taṇhāya pahāna ṭṭhena
translated: in the sense of having abandoned craving,🔽in the sense of being completely free from lust,🔽in the sense of being completely free from hatred,

analyzed: ekaḥ ekanta vīta rāgaḥ iti ekaḥ ekanta vīta dosaḥ iti ekaḥ ekanta vīta mohaḥ iti ekaḥ ekanta nikkilesaḥ iti

analyzed: ñāti pali bodham chinditvā sannidhi pali bodham chinditvā kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni
translated: having cut off the bonds of relatives, having cut off the bonds of wealth, having shaved off his hair and beard,

analyzed: vatthāni a chādetvā agārasmaā anagāriyam pabbajitvā akiñcana bhāvam upagantvā ekaḥ carati

analyzed: viharati iriyati vattā iti pāleti yapeti yāpeti iti

analyzed: katham saḥ paccekasambuddhaḥ a dutiya ṭṭhena ekaḥ

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno eko araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni.

translated: After going forth thus, he resorts to remote lodgings in the forest, in the open air, or in a cemetery, places that are secluded, with little sound, with little noise, far from the madding crowd, favourable for seclusion.

original: So eko gacchati, eko tiṭṭhati, eko nisīdati, eko seyyaṁ kappeti, eko gāmaṁ piṇḍāya🔽pavisati, eko abhikkamati, eko paṭikkamati, eko raho nisīdati, eko caṅkamaṁ adhiṭṭhāti,
analyzed: saḥ ekaḥ gacchati ekaḥ tiṭṭhati ekaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ seyyam kappeti ekaḥ gāmam piṇḍāya  pavisati ekaḥ abhikkamati ekaḥ paṭikkamati ekaḥ rahaḥ nisīdati ekaḥ caṅkamam adhiṭṭhāti
translated: Alone he goes, alone he returns, alone he sits, alone he lies down, alone he asks for requisites,🔽alone he goes to the village for alms, alone he returns, alone he eats, alone he goes to sit in the seclusion of his lodging, alone he walks in meditation,

analyzed: evam so paccekasambuddhaḥ a dutiya ṭṭhena ekaḥ
translated: Thus the Paccekabuddha is alone in the sense of having no second.

original: Kathaṁ so paccekasambuddho taṇhāya pahānaṭṭhena eko?

translated: How is the Paccekabuddha alone in the sense of the abandoning of craving?

analyzed: saḥ evam ekaḥ adutiyaḥ appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ mahāpadhānam padahantaḥ
translated: Living thus, alone and diligent, he makes great effort,

analyzed: sa senakam namucim kaṇham pamatta bandhum vidhametvā ca taṇhājālinim visaritam visattika

analyzed: taṇhā dutiyaḥ purisaḥ  dīghamaddhāna sasara
translated: “A man who is a slave to craving,🔽wandering on a long path,

analyzed: ittha bhāva ñathā bhāva
translated: the state of being a woman and the state of being a man,

analyzed: sa sāram na ativattati
translated: he does not escape from saṃsāra.

analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā
translated: Having known this danger,

analyzed: taṇham dukkhassa sambhava  vīta taṇhaḥ an ādānaḥ
translated: craving, the origin of suffering,🔽the monk who is free from craving, without grasping,

analyzed: sataḥ bhikkhu paribbajeti
translated: mindful, should wander forth.”

original: Evaṁ so paccekasambuddho taṇhāya pahānaṭṭhena eko.
analyzed: evam so paccekasambuddhaḥ taṇhāya pahāna ṭṭhena ekaḥ
translated: Thus that Independent Sambuddha was alone in the sense of abandoning craving.

analyzed: katham saḥ paccekasambuddhaḥ ekanta vīta rāgaḥ ti ekaḥ
translated: How was that Independent Sambuddha alone in the sense of being completely free from passion?

original: Rāgassa pahīnattā ekantavītarāgoti eko, dosassa pahīnattā ekantavītadosoti eko, mohassa pahīnattā ekantavītamohoti eko, kilesānaṁ pahīnattā ekantanikkilesoti eko.
analyzed: rāgassa pahīnattā ekanta vīta rāgaḥ iti ekaḥ dosassa pahīnattā ekanta vīta dosaḥ iti ekaḥ mohassa pahīnattā ekanta vīta mohaḥ iti ekaḥ kilesānam pahīnattā ekanta nikkilesaḥ iti ekaḥ
translated: He was alone in the sense of being completely free from passion because of the abandonment of passion, he was alone in the sense of being completely free from hatred because of the abandonment of hatred, he was alone in the sense of being completely free from delusion because of the abandonment of delusion, he was alone in the sense of being completely free from defilements because of the abandonment of defilements.

analyzed: evam saḥ paccekasambuddhaḥ ekanta vīta rāgaḥ ti ekaḥ

original: Ekāyanamaggo vuccati cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅgā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
analyzed: ekāyana maggaḥ vuccati cattāro sati paṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañca indriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjhaṅgāḥ ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: The one-way path is said to be the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five spiritual faculties, the five spiritual powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the noble eightfold path.

analyzed: eka ayanam jāti khayanta dassī
translated: “The one-way path, seeing the end of birth,

analyzed: maggam pajānāti hita anukampī

analyzed: tarissanti ye ca taranti oghanti

original: Evaṁ so paccekasambuddho ekāyanamaggaṁ gatoti eko.
analyzed: evam so paccekasambuddhaḥ ekāyana maggam gataḥ ti ekaḥ
translated: Thus that Independent Buddha went the one-way path, so he is one.

analyzed: katham saḥ paccekasambuddhaḥ ekaḥ anuttaram paccekasambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ iti ekaḥ

analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattā ati bujjhi

analyzed: avijjā paccayā saṅkhārā ti

analyzed: upādāna paccayā bhavoti  bhava paccayā jātī ti

analyzed: jāti paccayā jarā maraṇanti

analyzed: avijjā nirodhā saṅkhāra nirodho ti

analyzed: saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho ti bujjhi  viññāṇa nirodhā nāma rūpa nirodho ti bujjhi
translated: “With the cessation of (volitional) processes, there is the cessation of consciousness,” he comprehended.🔽“With the cessation of consciousness, there is the cessation of mind and bodily form,” he comprehended.

analyzed: saḷāyatana nirodhā phassa nirodho ti  phassa nirodhā vedanā nirodho ti

analyzed: vedanā nirodhā taṇhā nirodhaḥ ti

analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati

analyzed: ime āsavāti bujjhi  ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti pe

translated: Because of developing loving kindness, because of developing compassion, because of developing empathetic joy, because of developing equanimity, the beings in the eastern direction are not repulsive. …

original: ye disāsu vidisāsu sattā te appaṭikūlā hontīti—

translated: are addicted to such unedifying pursuits as watching dancing, singing, music, plays, mime, dancing-girls, storytelling, drumming, and cymbals;

original: meṇḍayuddhaṁ kukkuṭayuddhaṁ vaṭṭakayuddhaṁ daṇḍayuddhaṁ muṭṭhiyuddhaṁ nibbuddhaṁ🔽uyyodhikaṁ balaggaṁ senābyūhaṁ anīkadassanaṁ iti vā.
analyzed: meṇḍa yuddham kukkuṭa yuddham vaṭṭaka yuddham daṇḍa yuddham muṭṭhi yuddham nibbuddha 🔽uyyodhikam balaggam senā byūham anīka dassanam iti vā
translated: monks, shows with men, shows with women, shows with children, shows with old people, shows with dwarfs, shows with hunchbacks, shows with foreigners, shows with fighting bulls, shows with fighting rams, shows with fighting goats, shows with fighting cocks, shows with fighting quail, shows with wrestling, shows with fighting on horseback, shows with stick-fighting, shows with boxing, shows with fighting with shields and spears, battles, troop inspections, parades, massacres, rumors of battles, and rumors of troop inspections;

analyzed: iti evarūpam visūka dassanam anuyuttaḥ hoti
translated: He is intent on such foolish talk.

analyzed: evam pi khitta cakkhu hoti
translated: That is how he is one who looks this way and that.

analyzed: katham okkhitta cakkhu hoti
translated: How is he one who looks to the past?

original: Idhekacco bhikkhu na cakkhulolo na cakkhuloliyena samannāgato hoti.🔽Adiṭṭhaṁ dakkhitabbaṁ diṭṭhaṁ samatikkamitabbanti—🔽na ārāmena ārāmaṁ na uyyānena uyyānaṁ na gāmena gāmaṁ na nigamena nigamaṁ na nagarena
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu na cakkhulolaḥ na cakkhuloliyena samannāgataḥ hoti  a diṭṭham dakkhitabbam diṭṭham samatikkamitabbanti  na ārāmena ārāmam na uyyānena uyyānam na gāmena gāmam na nigamena nigamam na nagarena
translated: Here a bhikkhu is not one who is a gossip or a teller of tales,🔽thinking: ‘I have not seen what others have seen, others have seen what I have not seen.’🔽He does not go on a wandering tour without a purpose,🔽wandering from village to town or from town to village, from town to town, from district to district, from kingdom to kingdom,

original: nagaraṁ na raṭṭhena raṭṭhaṁ na janapadena janapadaṁ dīghacārikaṁ anavaṭṭhitacārikaṁ
analyzed: nagaram na raṭṭhena raṭṭham na janapadena janapadam dīghacārikam anavaṭṭhita cārika
translated: aimlessly wandering about the country.

analyzed: anuyuttaḥ hoti rūpa dassanāya  evam okkhitta cakkhu hoti
translated: That is how he is one who looks to the past.

original: Atha vā bhikkhu antaragharaṁ paviṭṭho vīthiṁ paṭipanno saṁvuto gacchati.🔽Na hatthiṁ olokento na assaṁ olokento na rathaṁ olokento na pattiṁ olokento na kumārake
analyzed: atha vā bhikkhu antara gharam paviṭṭhaḥ vīthim paṭipanno savutaḥ gacchati  na hatthim olokentaḥ na assam olokentaḥ na ratham olokentaḥ na pattim olokentaḥ na kumārake
translated: Or else, when a bhikkhu enters an inhabited area, he goes with his eyes downcast,🔽not looking at men, women, boys, or girls.

original: olokento na kumārikāyo olokento na itthiyo olokento na purise olokento na antarāpaṇaṁ
analyzed: olokentaḥ na kumārikāyaḥ olokentaḥ na itthiyaḥ olokentaḥ na purise olokentaḥ na antarāpaṇa
translated: He does not look at a house, a wall, a gateway, a tree, or a piece of furniture.

original: olokento na gharamukhāni olokento na uddhaṁ olokento na adho olokento na disāvidisaṁ
analyzed: olokentaḥ na ghara mukhāni olokentaḥ na uddham olokentaḥ na adhas olokentaḥ na disāvidisa
translated: He doesn’t look at the doors of houses, he doesn’t look up, he doesn’t look down, he doesn’t look around.

analyzed: vipekkhamānaḥ gacchati
translated: He walks mindfully.

analyzed: evam pi okkhitta cakkhu hoti
translated: In this way he is one who looks ahead only a short distance.

original: Atha vā bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.🔽Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: atha vā bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: Or else, seeing a sight with the eye, he doesn’t grasp at its general appearance or its details.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: If he were to leave the eye faculty unrestrained, evil unskillful qualities such as greed or distress might invade him, so he practices with restraint, he guards the eye faculty, he achieves restraint with regard to the eye faculty.

analyzed: evam pi okkhitta cakkhu hoti
translated: In this way he is one who looks ahead only a short distance.🔽Or, in the same way as some contemplatives & brahmans who live devoted to endurance, devoted to enduring, endure while enduring various kinds of pain & distress,

original: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṁ visūkadassanaṁ anuyuttā viharanti, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: yathā vā pana eke bhontaḥ samaṇa brāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpam visūka dassanam anuyuttāḥ viharanti
translated: such as beating, stabbing, cutting, and slicing,

original: naccaṁ gītaṁ vāditaṁ …pe… anīkadassanaṁ iti vā.
analyzed: naccam gītam vāditam pe anīka dassanam iti vā
translated: so too, the monk endures while enduring various kinds of pain & distress that arise, such as those produced by wind, bile, or phlegm, or the combination of the three, or those born of changes in temperature, or of irregular bodily humors, or of direct contact with sharp weapons, or of assault by others.

original: Iti evarūpā visūkadassanā paṭivirato.🔽Evampi okkhittacakkhu hoti.
analyzed: iti evarūpā visūka dassanā paṭivirataḥ 🔽evam pi okkhitta cakkhu hoti
translated: In this way he is one who looks ahead only a short distance.

original: Na ca pādaloloti kathaṁ pādalolo hoti?
analyzed: na ca katham pāda lolaḥ iti
translated: And not a foot-wanderer: How is one a foot-wanderer?

original: Idhekacco bhikkhu pādalolo pādaloliyena samannāgato hoti—
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu pāda lolaḥ pāda loliyena samannāgataḥ hoti
translated: It may be that a monk is a foot-wanderer, one who goes about on foot,

original: ārāmena ārāmaṁ uyyānena uyyānaṁ gāmena gāmaṁ nigamena nigamaṁ nagarena nagaraṁ raṭṭhena raṭṭhaṁ janapadena janapadaṁ dīghacārikaṁ anavaṭṭhitacārikaṁ anuyutto hoti.
analyzed: ārāmena ārāmam uyyānena uyyānam gāmena gāmam nigamena nigamam nagarena nagaram raṭṭhena raṭṭham janapadena janapadam dīgha cārikam anavaṭṭhita cārikam anuyuttaḥ hoti
translated: going from monastery to monastery, from park to park, from town to town, from village to village, from country to country, not staying in one place.

analyzed: evam pi pāda lolaḥ hoti
translated: In this way one is a foot-wanderer.

original: Atha vā bhikkhu antosaṅghārāme pādalolo pādaloliyena samannāgato hoti, na atthahetu
analyzed: atha vā bhikkhu antosaṅgha ārāme pāda lolo pāda loliyena samannāgataḥ hoti na attha hetu
translated: Or else a monk is a foot-wanderer within the monastery, not for a good reason,

original: na kāraṇahetu uddhato avūpasantacitto pariveṇato pariveṇaṁ gacchati, vihārato vihāraṁ🔽gacchati, aḍḍhayogato aḍḍhayogaṁ gacchati, pāsādato pāsādaṁ gacchati, hammiyato hammiyaṁ
analyzed: na kāraṇa hetu uddhataḥ a vūpasanta cittaḥ pariveṇataḥ pariveṇam gacchati vihārataḥ vihāra  gacchati aḍḍhayogataḥ aḍḍhayogam gacchati pāsādataḥ pāsādam gacchati hammiyataḥ hammiya
translated: not for a proper reason, but with a restless mind, his mind not settled. He goes from the outer cloister to the inner cloister, from the inner cloister to the outer cloister,🔽from the assembly hall to the monastery, from the monastery to the water-boiling shed, from the water-boiling shed to the monastery,🔽from the stilt house to the monastery, from the monastery to the stilt house,

original: gacchati, guhato guhaṁ gacchati, leṇato leṇaṁ gacchati, kuṭiyā kuṭiṁ gacchati, kūṭāgārato
analyzed: gacchati guhataḥ guham gacchati leṇataḥ leṇam gacchati kuṭiyā kuṭim gacchati kūṭāgārataḥ
translated: from the leaf hut to the stilt house, from the stilt house to the leaf hut, from the leaf hut to the leaf hut, from the stilt house to the stilt house.

original: kūṭāgāraṁ gacchati, aṭṭato aṭṭaṁ gacchati, māḷato māḷaṁ gacchati, uddaṇḍato uddaṇḍaṁ
analyzed: kūṭāgāram gacchati aṭṭataḥ aṭṭam gacchati māḷataḥ māḷam gacchati uddaṇḍataḥ uddaṇḍa
translated: he goes from mansion to mansion, from tower to tower, from terrace to terrace, from balcony to balcony,

original: gacchati, upaṭṭhānasālato upaṭṭhānasālaṁ gacchati, maṇḍapato maṇḍapaṁ gacchati, rukkhamūlato
analyzed: gacchati upaṭṭhāna sālataḥ upaṭṭhāna sālam gacchati maṇḍapataḥ maṇḍapam gacchati rukkha mūlataḥ
translated: He goes from stilt house to stilt house, from mansion to mansion, from gabled hall to gabled hall, from terrace to terrace, from upper to lower apartments, from park to town, from town to park, from street to street, from cross-road to cross-road, from market town to market town, from district to district, from capital to capital, from country to country, from island to island, from one inhabited place to another,🔽wherever there are monks, there he goes.

original: rukkhamūlaṁ gacchati, yattha vā pana bhikkhū nisīdanti vā gacchanti vā, tattha ekassa🔽vā dutiyo hoti, dvinnaṁ vā tatiyo hoti, tiṇṇaṁ vā catuttho hoti.🔽Tattha bahuṁ samphappalāpaṁ palapati, seyyathidaṁ—🔽rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ …pe…
analyzed: rukkha mūlam gacchati yattha vā pana bhikkhū nisīdanti vā gacchanti vā tattha ekassa  vā dutiyaḥ hoti dvinnam vā tatiyaḥ hoti tiṇṇam vā catutthaḥ hoti  tattha bahum samphappalāpam palapati  rāja katham cora katham pe
translated: There he engages in much useless chatter:

analyzed: iti bhava abhava katham kathā iti
translated: talk about kings, talk about thieves, talk about ministers, talk about armies, talk about dangers, talk about wars, talk about food, talk about drinks, talk about clothes, talk about beds, talk about garlands, talk about scents, talk about relatives, talk about vehicles, talk about villages, talk about towns, talk about cities, talk about states, talk about women, talk about heroes, talk about heavens, talk about the departed, talk about what is not, talk about the variety of mundane topics.

original: Evampi pādalolo hoti.🔽Na ca pādaloloti so paccekasambuddho pādaloliyā ārato virato paṭivirato nikkhanto
analyzed: evam pi pāda lolaḥ hoti  na ca pāda lolo ti so paccekasambuddho pāda loliyā ārataḥ virataḥ paṭivirataḥ nikkhanto
translated: In this way he is a wanderer by foot.🔽Not a wanderer by foot: that Independent Buddha is not interested in or devoted to wandering by foot. He has abandoned wandering by foot, eliminated it, done away with it, discarded it, let go of it, forsaken it, thrown it aside.

original: nissaṭo vippamutto visaññutto vimariyādikatena cetasā paṭisallānārāmo hoti paṭisallānarato
analyzed: nissaṭaḥ vippamuttaḥ visaññuttaḥ vimariyādikatena cetasā paṭisallāna ārāmaḥ hoti paṭisallāna rataḥ
translated: He delights in and is devoted to seclusion, to solitary meditation.

original: ajjhattaṁ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno vipassanāya samannāgato brūhetā suññāgāraṁ
analyzed: ajjhattam cetaḥ samatham anuyuttaḥ a nirākata jhānaḥ vipassanāya samannāgataḥ brūheta suññāgāra
translated: He is intent on the mind’s calm within, and he has the discernment that comes from the ending of defilements. He is a speaker, and he uses the empty place.

analyzed: jhāyī jhāna rataḥ ekatta manuyuttaḥ sadattha garukaḥ ti
translated: He is a meditator, devoted to meditation, intent on solitude, and he values his own benefit.

analyzed: na ca pāda lolo
translated: He is one who casts off, and he is not one who goes about aimlessly.

analyzed: guttindriyaḥ
translated: He is one who guards the sense doors, and he is one who protects his mind.

original: Guttindriyoti so paccekasambuddho cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.🔽Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: gutti indriyaḥ ti so paccekasambuddhaḥ cakkhunā rūpam disvā na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī  yatvā adhikaraṇam enam cakkhu indriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: “He is one who guards the sense doors”: When the Private Buddha sees a visible object with the eye, he does not grasp at its general appearance or its details.🔽If he were to live without guarding the faculty of the eye, evil unwholesome states of covetousness and grief would invade him, and he would say, “I live without guarding the faculty of the eye.”

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: He practises for the obtaining of the unguarded state, he guards the faculty of the eye, and he attains the guarding of the faculty of the eye.

analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā pe  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā
translated: When he hears a sound with the ear…🔽smells an odour with the nose…

analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā
translated: tastes a flavour with the tongue…

analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā
translated: touches a tangible with the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: cognizes a mind-object with the mind, he does not grasp at its general appearance or its details.

original: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā🔽dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam man indriyam viharantam abhijjhā domanassā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ  dhammā anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati manindriya manindriye
translated: If he doesn’t guard the mind faculty, evil unskillful qualities such as greed or aversion overwhelm him.🔽For the restraint of his mind faculty he practices guarding it, he protects the mind faculty,

analyzed: savaram āpajjati iti  gutti indriyaḥ  rakkhita mānasāno ti gopita mānasāno ti
translated: he achieves restraint over the mind faculty.🔽He is one who guards the sense doors.

analyzed: guttindriyaḥ
translated: He is one who has guarded his mind.🔽He is one who is not overcome by desire.

analyzed: an avassutaḥ pariḍayhamānaḥ ti vuttam ha etam āyasmatā mahāmoggallānena
translated: This is what was said by Ven. Mahā Moggallāna:

analyzed: avassuta pariyāyam ca vaḥ āvuso desessāmi an avassuta pariyāyam ca
translated: “Friends, I will teach you the way that is conducive to being overcome by desire and the way that is conducive to not being overcome by desire.

original: Taṁ suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tam suṇātha sādhukam manasi karotha bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and pay careful attention to what I will say.”

original: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: evam āvuso ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmataḥ mahāmoggallānassa
translated: “As you say, friend,” the monks replied.

analyzed: āyasmai mahāmoggallānaḥ etat avoca
translated: Ven. Mahā Moggallāna said this:

analyzed: kathañca āvuso avassutaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is one overcome by desire?

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe adhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati parittacetaso.
analyzed: idha āvuso bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpam disvā piya rūpe rūpe adhimuccati appiya rūpe rūpe byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: There is the case where a monk, on seeing a form via the eye, becomes enamored with a form that inspires desire. He places confidence in what is inspiring desire. He dwells with a mind that is not fully concentrated, with a mind that is limited.

original: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not discern, as it actually is, the awareness-release & discernment-release where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without remainder.

analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā pe
translated: On hearing a sound via the ear…🔽On smelling an odor via the nose…🔽On tasting a flavor via the tongue…🔽On touching a tactile sensation via the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya piyarūpe dhamme adhimuccati, appiyarūpe dhamme byāpajjati, anupaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati parittacetaso.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya piya rūpe dhamme adhimuccati appiya rūpe dhamme byāpajjati an upaṭṭhita kāyassati ca viharati paritta cetasaḥ
translated: On cognizing an idea via the intellect, he becomes enamored with an idea that inspires desire. He places confidence in what is inspiring desire. He dwells with a mind that is not fully concentrated, with a mind that is limited.

original: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
analyzed: tat ca cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim yathābhūtam na pajānāti yattha assa te uppannā pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti
translated: He does not discern, as it actually is, the awareness-release & discernment-release where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without remainder.🔽This is called a monk who is not released from the forms cognizable via the eye,

original: Ayaṁ vuccatāvuso, bhikkhu avassuto cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu …pe…
analyzed: ayam vuccati āvuso bhikkhu cakkhu viññeyyesu rūpesu pe
translated: not released from the sounds cognizable via the ear,🔽not released from the aromas cognizable via the nose,🔽not released from the flavors cognizable via the tongue,🔽not released from the tactile sensations cognizable via the body,

analyzed: avassutaḥ manaḥ viññeyyesu dhammesu
translated: not released from the ideas cognizable via the intellect.

original: Evaṁvihāriñcāvuso, bhikkhuṁ cakkhuto cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhetheva māro otāraṁ labhetha māro ārammaṇaṁ,
analyzed: evavihārin ca āvuso bhikkhum cakkhutaḥ ce pi nam māraḥ upasaṅkamati labhetha iva māraḥ otāram labhetha māraḥ
translated: If Mara comes upon a bhikkhu who abides in this way through the eye, Mara finds no lodgement and gains no opportunity.

analyzed: saḥ t taḥ ca ipi nam pe
translated: If Mara comes upon him through the ear…

original: manato cepi naṁ māro upasaṅkamati, labhetheva māro otāraṁ labhetha māro ārammaṇaṁ.
analyzed: ce ipi nam māro upasaṅkamati labhetha iva māro otāram labhetha māro
translated: through the mind, Mara finds no lodgement and gains no opportunity.

original: Seyyathāpi, āvuso, naḷāgāraṁ vā tiṇāgāraṁ vā sukkhaṁ koḷāpaṁ terovassikaṁ.🔽Puratthimāya cepi naṁ disāya puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya, labhetheva aggi otāraṁ labhetha aggi ārammaṇaṁ;🔽pacchimāya cepi naṁ disāya …pe…
analyzed: seyyathā api āvuso naḷāgāram vā tiṇa āgāram vā sukkham koḷāpam terovassika  puratthimāya ce pi nam disāya purisaḥ ādittāya tiṇukkāya upasaṅkameyya labhetha iva aggi otāram labhetha aggi ārammaṇa  pacchimāya nam disāya
translated: Suppose there were a dry, withered piece of wood,🔽and a man came with an upper fire-stick, thinking: ‘I shall light a fire, I shall produce heat.’🔽If he rubbed it against that dry, withered piece of wood, he would light a fire and produce heat.

original: uttarāya cepi naṁ disāya …🔽dakkhiṇāya cepi naṁ disāya …
analyzed: uttarāya nam disāya  dakkhiṇāya cepi nam disāya
translated: If he rubbed it against that dry, withered piece of wood, he would light a fire and produce heat.🔽If he rubbed it against that dry, withered piece of wood, he would light a fire and produce heat.

original: Idhāvuso, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā piyarūpe rūpe nādhimuccati, appiyarūpe rūpe na byāpajjati, upaṭṭhitakāyassati ca viharati appamāṇacetaso.

Since, if he left the eye faculty unrestrained, bad unwholesome states of covetousness and grief might invade him, he practices restraint over it; he guards the eye faculty; he undertakes the restraint, of the eye faculty.

original: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti;

original: Tañca cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, yatthassa te uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā aparisesā nirujjhanti.

translated: And he understands as it really is that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, where those arisen bad unwholesome states of his cease without remainder.🔽“A bhikkhu who dwells thus ardently, arousing his energy thus, is called a bhikkhu who is ardent and clearly comprehending, one who dwells attaining jhana in each moment of his life.

original: khārikaṁ labhitvā akhārikaṁ pariyesanti, akhārikaṁ labhitvā khārikaṁ pariyesanti;🔽kasāvaṁ labhitvā akasāvaṁ pariyesanti, akasāvaṁ labhitvā kasāvaṁ pariyesanti;
analyzed: khārikam labhitvā a khārikam pariyesanti a khārikam labhitvā khārikam pariyesanti  kasāvam labhitvā a kasāvam pariyesanti a kasāvam labhitvā kasāvam pariyesanti
translated: When they get sour they look for non-sour, and when they get non-sour they look for sour.🔽When they get astringent they look for non-astringent, and when they get non-astringent they look for astringent.

original: lambikaṁ labhitvā alambikaṁ pariyesanti, alambikaṁ labhitvā lambikaṁ pariyesanti;🔽sāduṁ labhitvā asāduṁ pariyesanti, asāduṁ labhitvā sāduṁ pariyesanti;
analyzed: lambikam labhitvā a lambikam pariyesanti a lambikam labhitvā lambikam pariyesanti  sādum labhitvā asādum pariyesanti asādum labhitvā sādum pariyesanti
translated: When they get bitter they look for non-bitter, and when they get non-bitter they look for bitter.🔽When they get sweet they look for non-sweet, and when they get non-sweet they look for sweet.

original: sītaṁ labhitvā uṇhaṁ pariyesanti, uṇhaṁ labhitvā sītaṁ pariyesanti.
analyzed: sītam labhitvā uṇham pariyesanti uṇham labhitvā sītam pariyesanti
translated: When they get hot they look for cold, and when they get cold they look for hot.

original: Te yaṁ yaṁ labhanti tena tena na tussanti, aparāparaṁ pariyesanti.
analyzed: te yam yam labhanti tena tena na tussanti apara aparam pariyesanti
translated: They are not satisfied with whatever they get, and they look for more and more.

original: Manāpikesu rasesu rattā giddhā gathitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā.
analyzed: manāpikesu rasesu rattā giddhā gathitā mucchitā ajjhosannā laggā laggitā palibuddhā
translated: They are greedy for, attached to, infatuated with, and tied to delightful tastes, and they are dependent, attached, and bound to them.

original: Sā rasataṇhā tassa paccekasambuddhassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
analyzed: sā rasa taṇhā tassa paccekasambuddhassa pahīnā ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatim an uppāda dhammā
translated: The craving for tastes was abandoned by that Paccekabuddha, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that it is no more subject to future arising.

original: Tasmā so paccekasambuddho paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṁ āhāreti—
analyzed: tasmā so paccekasambuddho paṭisaṅkhā yonisas āhāram āhāreti
translated: So that Paccekabuddha, reflecting wisely, took food,

original: “neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya;
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya
translated: not for sport, for indulgence, for smartening, or for adorning,

original: yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya.
analyzed: yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihisūparatiyā brahmacariya anuggahāya
translated: but only for the survival and continuance of this body, for ending discomfort, and for assisting the holy life,

original: Iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā”ti.🔽Yathā vaṇaṁ ālimpeyya yāvadeva āruhaṇatthāya, yathā vā akkhaṁ abbhañjeyya yāvadeva
analyzed: iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati  yathā vaṇam ālimpeyya yāvat eva āruhaṇa atthāya yathā vā akkham abbhañjeyya yāvat eva
translated: thinking: ‘Thus will I destroy old feelings and not create new feelings, and I shall be living comfortably, without guilt, and in a fit state for spiritual practice.’🔽Just as one might apply ointment to a wound only in order to heal it,🔽or just as one might oil an axle only in order to convey a load,

original: bhārassa nittharaṇatthāya, yathā puttamaṁsaṁ āhāraṁ āhareyya yāvadeva kantārassa nittharaṇatthāya;
analyzed: bhārassa nittharaṇa tthāya yathā putta masam āhāram āhareyya yāvat eva kantārassa nittharaṇa tthāya
translated: or just as one might feed a draught animal only in order to get it to pull a load,

original: evameva so paccekasambuddho paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṁ āhāreti—
analyzed: evam eva so paccekasambuddhaḥ paṭisaṅkhā yonisas āhāram āhāreti
translated: so that Paccekabuddha, reflecting wisely, took food,

original: “neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya;
analyzed: na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya
translated: ‘Not for the sake of enjoyment, intoxication, adornment, or decoration,

original: yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṁsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya.
analyzed: yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihisūparatiyā brahmacariya anuggahāya
translated: but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual life.

original: Iti purāṇañca vedanaṁ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṁ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā”ti.
analyzed: iti purāṇam ca vedanam paṭihaṅkhāmi navam ca vedanam na uppādessāmi yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajja tā ca phāsu vihāraḥ ca ati
translated: Thus I will put an end to old feelings without arousing new ones, and I will be healthy, blameless, and comfortable.’

original: Rasataṇhāya ārato virato paṭivirato nikkhanto nissaṭo vippamutto visaññutto vimariyādikatena cetasā viharatīti—
analyzed: rasa taṇhāya ārataḥ virataḥ paṭivirataḥ nikkhantaḥ nissaṭaḥ vippamuttaḥ visaññuttaḥ vimariyādikatena cetasā viharati iti
translated: He is detached from craving for tastes,

analyzed: rasesu gedham akara
translated: I’ve no desire for tastes.

analyzed: alolo ti loluppam vuccati taṇhā
translated: ‘Lolup’ is a term for craving.

original: Yo rāgo sārāgo …pe… abhijjhā lobho akusalamūlaṁ.
analyzed: yaḥ rāgaḥ sa arāgaḥ pe abhijjhā lobho akusala mūla
translated: It’s the desire, the greed, the delighting in, the craving for, that is the root for unskillful qualities.

original: Sā loluppā taṇhā tassa paccekasambuddhassa pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṁ anuppādadhammā.
analyzed: sā loluppā taṇhā tassa paccekasambuddhassa pahīnā ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatim an uppāda dhammā
translated: That craving has been given up by the Independent Buddha, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated so that it’s no more subject to future arising.

original: Tasmā paccekasambuddho aloloti—🔽rasesu gedhaṁ akaraṁ alolo.
analyzed: tasmā paccekasambuddhaḥ aloloti  rasesu gedham akaram a lolaḥ
translated: That’s why the Independent Buddha is said to be ‘without desire’.🔽I’ve no desire for tastes.

analyzed: an añña posī sa padāna cārī iti
translated: I don’t eat for fun, but go out for alms with my eyes down.

original: anaññaposīti so paccekasambuddho attānaññeva poseti, na paranti.
analyzed: an añña posī iti so paccekasambuddhaḥ attā anaññā iva poseti na paranti
translated: He who does not live off others: this Paccekabuddha lives off himself, not off others.

analyzed: an añña posi maññāta  dantam sāre patiṭṭhita
translated: He who does not live off others,🔽tamed, established in truth,

analyzed: khīṇa āsavam vanta dosa
translated: his taints destroyed, his anger quelled—

analyzed: tam aham brūmi
translated: him I call a brahmin.

original: Anaññaposī sapadānacārīti so paccekasambuddho pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya
analyzed: an añña posī sa padāna cārī iti so paccekasambuddhaḥ pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya
translated: He who does not live off others, goes on his alms round: this Paccekabuddha, having dressed in the morning and taking his bowl and outer robe,

original: gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya pavisati rakkhiteneva kāyena rakkhitāya vācāya rakkhitena
analyzed: gāmam vā nigamam vā piṇḍāya pavisati rakkhitena iva kāyena rakkhitāya vācāya rakkhitena
translated: enters the village or town for alms with guarded body, guarded speech, guarded mind,

analyzed: cittena upaṭṭhitāya satiyā savutehi indriyehi
translated: with mindfulness established, with his senses restrained.

original: Okkhittacakkhu iriyāpathasampanno kulā kulaṁ anatikkamanto piṇḍāya caratīti—
analyzed: okkhitta cakkhu iriyāpatha sampanno kulā kulam an atikkamantaḥ piṇḍāya carati iti
translated: With eyes downcast, endowed with conduct, not overstepping the bounds of propriety, he goes for alms from house to house.

analyzed: an añña posī sa padāna cārī
translated: He who does not live off others, goes on his alms round.

original: Kule kule appaṭibaddhacittoti dvīhi kāraṇehi paṭibaddhacitto hoti—
analyzed: kule kule appaṭibaddha cittaḥ ti dvīhi kāraṇehi paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: He whose mind is not attached to any family: for two reasons one’s mind is attached:

original: attānaṁ vā nīcaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ uccaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti, attānaṁ vā uccaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ nīcaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti.
analyzed: attānam vā nīcam ṭhapentaḥ param uccam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti attānam vā uccam ṭhapentaḥ param nīcam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: one is attached because one makes oneself low and exalts another, or because one makes oneself high and demotes another.

original: Kathaṁ attānaṁ nīcaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ uccaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti?
analyzed: katham attānam nīcam ṭhapentaḥ param uccam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: How is it that when you put yourself down and put others up, you have a bound heart?

original: “Tumhe me bahūpakārā, ahaṁ tumhe nissāya labhāmi cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ.🔽Yampi me aññe dātuṁ vā kātuṁ vā maññanti tumhe nissāya tumhe passantā.
analyzed: tumhe me bahu upakārāḥ aham tumhe nissāya labhāmi cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāra  yam pi me aññe dātum vā kātum vā maññanti tumhe nissāya tumhe passantā
translated: “You’ve been very helpful to me. Because of you, I get robe-cloth, almsfood, dwellings, and medicinal supplies.🔽Because of you, others think to give and do for me.

original: Yampi me porāṇaṁ mātāpettikaṁ nāmagottaṁ tampi me antarahitaṁ tumhehi ahaṁ ñāyāmi—
analyzed: yam pi me porāṇam mātāpettikam nāma gottam tam pi me antarahitam tumhehi aham
translated: Because of you, my old family name and clan name have disappeared. I’m known as

analyzed: asukassa kulupakaḥ asukāya kulupakaḥ ti
translated: ‘so-and-so’s disciple.’”

original: Evaṁ attānaṁ nīcaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ uccaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti.
analyzed: evam attānam nīcam ṭhapentaḥ param uccam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how it’s when you put yourself down and put others up that you have a bound heart.

original: Kathaṁ attānaṁ uccaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ nīcaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti?
analyzed: katham attānam uccam ṭhapentaḥ param nīcam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: How is it that when you put yourself up and put others down, you have a bound heart?

original: “Ahaṁ tumhākaṁ bahūpakāro, tumhe maṁ āgamma buddhaṁ saraṇaṁ gatā dhammaṁ saraṇaṁ
analyzed: aham tumhākam bahu upakāro tumhe mam āgamma buddham saraṇam gatāḥ dhammam saraṇa
translated: “I’ve been very helpful to you. Because of me, you’ve gone for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha.

original: gatā saṅghaṁ saraṇaṁ gatā, pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā, adinnādānā paṭiviratā, kāmesumicchācārā
analyzed: gatā saṅgham saraṇam gatā pāṇa atipātā paṭiviratā adinna ādānā paṭiviratā kāmesum icchā ācārā
translated: You’ve given up killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct.

original: paṭiviratā, musāvādā paṭiviratā, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā, tumhākaṁ
analyzed: paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānā paṭiviratā tumhāka
translated: You’re abstaining from lying, from alcohol, and from high and luxurious resting places.

original: ahaṁ uddesaṁ demi paripucchaṁ demi uposathaṁ ācikkhāmi navakammaṁ adhiṭṭhāmi;
analyzed: aham uddesam demi paripuccham demi uposatham ācikkhāmi nava kammam adhiṭṭhāmi
translated: I give you the recitation, I give you the interrogation, I announce the observance day, I authorize building work.

original: atha ca pana tumhe maṁ ujjhitvā aññe sakkarotha garuṁ karotha mānetha pūjethā”ti.
analyzed: atha ca pana tumhe mam ujjhitvā aññe sakkarotha garum karotha mānetha pūjetha ati
translated: But you’ve abandoned me and honor others instead.”

original: Evaṁ attānaṁ uccaṁ ṭhapento paraṁ nīcaṁ ṭhapento paṭibaddhacitto hoti.
analyzed: evam attānam uccam ṭhapentaḥ param nīcam ṭhapentaḥ paṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti
translated: In this way, he elevates himself and disparages others because of his close ties.

analyzed: kule kule appaṭibaddha cittaḥ ti so paccekasambuddhaḥ kula palibodhena appaṭibaddha cittaḥ  hoti gaṇa palibodhena appaṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti āvāsa palibodhena appaṭibaddha cittaḥ  hoti cīvara palibodhena appaṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti piṇḍapāta palibodhena appaṭibaddha cittaḥ

translated: or to medicines and supplies for the sick.

analyzed: kule kule appaṭibaddha cittaḥ hoti ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo

analyzed: kule kule appaṭibaddha cittaḥ
translated: not attached to any family,

analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti
translated: he goes alone like the horn of the rhinoceros.”🔽Having abandoned the five hindrances,

analyzed: pahāya pañca āvaraṇāni cetasaḥ iti saḥ paccekasambuddhaḥ kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam pahāya pajahitvā vinodetvā byantīkaritvā anabhāvam gametvā byāpāda nīvaraṇam
translated: having abandoned, removed, done away with, rejected, let go of, given up ill will as a hindrance,🔽having abandoned, removed, done away with, rejected, let go of, given up sloth & drowsiness as a hindrance,

analyzed: thinam iddha nīvaraṇam  uddhacca kukkucca nīvaraṇam
translated: having abandoned, removed, done away with, rejected, let go of, given up restlessness & anxiety as a hindrance,

translated: having abandoned, removed, done away with, rejected, let go of, given up uncertainty as a hindrance,🔽secluded from sensuality, secluded from unskillful qualities,

original: Sutavāti so paccekasambuddho bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo.
analyzed: sutavāti so paccekasambuddhaḥ bahu ssutaḥ hoti suta dharaḥ suta sannicayo
translated: He is learned: he is one who has heard much, he remembers what he has heard, he has stored what he has heard.

original: Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ🔽parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā

translated: Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with their own meaning, with their own phrasing, that proclaim the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—

analyzed: vacasā paricitā manasā anupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā
translated: such teachings as these he has heard much of, has remembered, has recited verbally, has investigated with the mind, and has well penetrated with wisdom.

original: Satīmāti so paccekasambuddho satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgatattā cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritāti—

analyzed: aneḍamūgaḥ sutavā satīmā

original: Saṅkhātadhammo niyato padhānavāti saṅkhātadhammo vuccati ñāṇaṁ.

original: Yā paññā pajānanā …pe… amoho dhammavicayo sammādiṭṭhi.🔽Saṅkhātadhammoti so paccekasambuddho saṅkhātadhammo ñātadhammo tulitadhammo tīritadhammo vibhūtadhammo vibhāvitadhammo “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”ti saṅkhātadhammo …pe…

original: “yaṁ kiñci samudayadhammaṁ sabbaṁ taṁ nirodhadhamman”ti saṅkhātadhammo ñātadhammo tulitadhammo tīritadhammo vibhūtadhammo vibhāvitadhammo.

translated: “All that is subject to arising is subject to cessation.” He was possessed of the Dhamma that is analyzed, the Dhamma that is known, the Dhamma that is discerned, the Dhamma that is penetrated, the Dhamma that is seen, the Dhamma that is attained, the Dhamma that is realized, the Dhamma that is comprehended.
